title: How to stop Firefox from invoking Apple podcast app on podcasts.apple.com
content:
Seems that on Monterey forward there no way to reset the OS's notion of the podcast player app.

When on podcasts.apple.com on a particular podcast, clicking play invokes podcasts.app.The easiest way for me to get the real podcast URL is copying the URL from podcasts.apple.com. Having Firefox invoke the default podcast app (which can't be changed) gets in the way of obtaining the URL.

Safari supposedly has has a setting to disable autoplay, but it ignores that setting when on podcasts.apple.com.

A good workaround would be a methodology to able to easily obtain the particular podcast episode's URL

Thank you.

title: unable to reach bank
content:
When I try to go on my bank's online site, I get this message. Did Not Connect: Potential Security Issue

Firefox detected a potential security threat and did not continue to onlinebanking.northwest.bank because this website requires a secure connection.

What can you do about it?

onlinebanking.northwest.bank has a security policy called HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS), which means that Firefox can only connect to it securely. You can’t add an exception to visit this site.

The issue is most likely with the website, and there is nothing you can do to resolve it. You can notify the website’s administrator about the problem.

Learn more…
creator: wbkennedy4

title: Firefox sync problems
content:
I don't quite know how to explain this.

My phone was upgraded, and I set up the Firefox mobile to sync, and now my desktop install has undergone some changes I tried to avoid, and I want to know if there s a way to reverse it, or avoid it in the future.

Previously, I posed a question about which device/install takes precedence when sync is enabled, because one side, generally my desktop, ends up suffering negative changes, which results in loss of information, i.e. history, addon settings reset to default, remembered logins no longer remembered, etc.

For these reasons, under typical circumstances, I do not enable sync on my desktop, but in order to have Firefox mobile equipped with the latest sessions, etc., I thought I could solve the desktop problem by backing up of my current profile to a different location, after which I could log in to sync, let it do it's job, and then return to my original profile, which is not set up to sync, and it would be as I left it.

But, that was not he case, and I suffered the loss of all but the last seven days of history, and all the other changes I listed above.

So now, not only do I have to set up all apps on the new phone, but on my desktop as well. Extremely frustrating.

In my experience, in some ways, sync acts more like a backup program, that deletes whatever is in the destination that is not in the source. I'm my mind, syncing should have an option to go in only "one direction", in this case, from my desktop to my mobile, not which one is the latest, which seem to be happening here.

There should also be an option to 'combine the data from the two sides.

I'd really like to get some feedback on the this. Perhaps I'm doing something wrong. If so, please help me deal with this.

title: Window is invisible if it isn't maximized
content:
Users sometimes report that they are activating a Firefox window (according to the Window Taskbar) but it can't be seen, even with a single-monitor, single-desktop setup. A temporary workaround is to maximize the window using either of these methods:

  • right-click the thumbnail image of the Window that floats above the Windows Taskbar button, then click Maximize (if there are numerous windows open, there will be a list of titles instead of thumbnails, but same method)
  • while the window is active, press Alt+Spacebar to call up the window control menu, then click Maximize

In the past, I've given the advice that you could bring the window back into view using the window control menu (Size, then right arrow, etc.). However, I discovered today that this wasn't practical because a window was so far offscreen to the left.

While the window was maximized, I used the web console (Ctrl+Shift+K) to capture the left and top positions of the window. Then I click the restore button on the title bar, the window vanished, and I re-ran the commands (without the benefit of being able to see, of course), and then I re-maximized the window. The news was bad:

Maximized:

09:43:15.730 window.screenX 09:43:15.756 -8 09:43:20.347 window.screenY 09:43:20.380 -8

Restored:

09:43:37.429 window.screenX 09:43:37.457 -31164 09:43:40.811 window.screenY 09:43:40.833 484

What would be perfect in this situation would be to run the JavaScript command

window.moveTo(0,0);

to pop the window into the upper left corner of the screen. But actually, this is considered the same as the page doing it, and pages are barred from using this method unless the window was launched by a script in the first place. That command does work in the Browser Console (Ctrl+Shift+J), but only if you have enabled the command line, which most user will not be aware of. (And it didn't occur to me in the moment so I proceeded with the next step...)

In my case, I quit Firefox and edited the xulstore.json file to fix this problem so that the window would be positioned normally at the next startup. That is similarly obscure, but it's kind of obvious once you get in there with a text editor.

The difficulty of quickly getting your window back into view makes me think that Firefox needs some kind of failsafe to prevent invisible windows. I'll probably file a bug report for that, but wanted to document this story before returning to regular work.

title: Usar o navegador em um HD externo
content:
Instalei o Firefox Developer Edition no meu HD externo pois uso o navegador em 2 ou mais computadores diferentes, só que o que está acontecendo é que a configuração do navegador está ficando salva no computador. Consegui criar meu perfil no navegador e salvar ele no HD externo, mas mesmo assim tem algumas configurações que ficam salvas no PC e preciso que fique salva no HD.

Criei o perfil usando o comando "firefox.exe -p", e coloquei a pasta dele no HD externo. Quando vou em "about:profiles" ele aparece lá e diz que está salvo no HD externo.

No "about:cache" em "disk" está salvo no HD externo também. Em cima, na opção "memory" não tem caminho.

Quando abro a pasta "programdata" no PC, tem uma pasta da Mozilla que foi criada, e tem outra em usuários/appdata/local.

Quando desconecto o HD externo e uso em outro computador, ele não encontra mais o usuário. Acredito acontecer isso por causa desses arquivos que ainda estão ficando salvos no PC em vez de estarem no HD.

Segue as imagens: cache, profiles, pasta programdata e pasta user/appdata/local.

A ultima mostra a pasta do meu perfil no HD externo.

title: Screen Glitches only in Firefox browser Slows PC so much forces me to reboot
content:

Moving the mouse all over the place makes it worse with more copies. It also slows all response from my computer to several seconds no matter what I try (closing the browser, opening task manager, etc). Sometimes I can get to the reboot screen and do it there, but most of the time everything is so slow I have to hit the power button on my HP which is the standby or sleep button so when I hit it again, I am at the login screen and can reboot there.

As I said, a single reboot normally solves the problem for the rest of the day or several days until tonight. I have a basic wired scroll mouse that I'm wondering if pressing down on it is causing Firefox to glitch. Otherwise, I've got no idea. Firefox has updated to 119, Windows 11 has updated a couple of times, my NVIDIA GeForce card driver updates weekly. I have no malware or viruses on my PC. Nothing is pulling hard on my resources as it only pulls 40% of my memory max when checking it in Task Manager when I can get it to open.
